subject: Re: [junit] Re: Do JUnit internals suck?!?
msgSnippet: Quoth Berin Loritsch: [...] ... Um.  Perhaps I m missing the point, but I d prefer to have the Test-creation logic outside of the TestRunner.  For example:
messageBody:
Quoth Berin Loritsch:
[...]
> The whole Name thing is irrelevant at this point. If a Test
> implements the TestFixture interface, then it will use reflection
> to pull all the interfaces. So the interface should be something
> like this:
>
> interface TestFixture
> {}
>
> When the Test Collector/Test Runner runs across any Class
> implementing TestFixture, it is converted into a group of
> Test objects. [...]

Um. Perhaps I'm missing the point, but I'd prefer to have the
Test-creation logic outside of the TestRunner. For example:

interface TestFactory {
Test makeTest();
}

class OneMethodTest implements Test {
OneMethodTest( Class c, Method m ) {
// ...
}
void run( TestResult result ) {
// instantiate c
// execute instance.setUp()
// execute instance.m
// execute instance.tearDown()
}
// ...
}

class ReflectiveTestFactory implements TestFactory {
ReflectiveTestFactory() {
// factory based on self
}
ReflectiveTestFactory( Class c ) {
// factory based on class c
}
Test makeTest() {
// scan c (or self) for test* methods
// make a OneMethodTest for each
// return a TestSuite containing those
}
}

For backwards compatibility, a TestRunner encountering a TestCase
can make a ReflectiveFactory for it. In general it expects to
encounter TestFactory implementations and let them make the Tests.

For new test implementations, it is sufficient to put test*
methods in a subclass of ReflectiveFactory. This is just like
subclassing TestCase now, but there's no need for the String
constructor (which might, as Meyers implied elsewhere in the
thread, encourage novice users to put setup in setUp() instead of
in the constructor).

If it is inconvenient to subclass ReflectiveFactory (as when the
tests rely on partaking of some other inheritance hierarchy), it
is convenient enough to write

class MyTests implements TestFactory {
Test makeTest() {
return new ReflectiveTestFactory(
this.getClass() ).makeTest();
}
// ...
}

As with the static suite() method, the advantage of this approach
is that tests can be generated however is desired. Unlike
suite(), makeTest() above is an instance method, which as
Silverstein points out elsewhere in the thread makes it easier to
make tests from other frameworks work as JUnit tests.
